answers.a: A refined clay mineral of magnesium, aluminum and silicate layers used mainly as a thickener/stabilizer and anti‑caking agent, similar in function to the magnesium silicates covered by E553 (e.g., talc/magnesium silicate).
Yes—when of food/cosmetic grade and used as authorized, it’s considered safe; it is insoluble, minimally absorbed, and specifications require it to be asbestos‑free and low in heavy metals.

answers.q: does magnesium aluminum silicate cause cancer
answers.a: There’s no evidence it causes cancer when asbestos‑free and used as intended; cancer concerns mainly involve inhalation of asbestos‑contaminated talc, not food/cosmetic‑grade materials.

answers.q: is magnesium aluminum silicate safe for skin
answers.a: Yes—cosmetic safety reviews consider it safe as used; it largely sits on the skin with minimal absorption, though avoiding inhalation of powders is advisable.

Food‑grade magnesium silicate (E553) is generally considered safe at permitted levels and is poorly absorbed; the main risks relate to inhaling fine talc dust or using non‑food‑grade/asbestos‑contaminated material.
